section.title: Overview
section.para: There are several instances when you will need to code in the CeltiXfire(CXF) documentation. You may need to use a class name, interface name, or element name as part of a sentence. You will also need to provide long code samples in many places. Docbook has a number of elements that are used for placing code in your documentation.

note.para: XML mark-up, such as WSDL and XMLSchema, are also considered code for the purposes of CXF documentation.

section.title: Examples
section.para: When providing code examples, you need to separate them from the text and provide a caption for them. To do this you use the example element. You should always provide a descriptive value for the example element's id attribute.

As shown in , the first child of the example element is a title element. The contents of the title element will be used as the caption of the example. It will also be used as the text for any cross references.

note.para: If you want to have different text appear when cross referencing an example, set the example element's xreflabel attribute.

section.para: The last child of the example element is the programlisting element. The programlisting element contains the code sample itself. Any text placed inside the programlisting element is treated literally. Therefore, any spacing that you use will be exactly reproduced when the document is produced.

warning.para: When using XML inside a programlisting element you must not use the < or >characters. Instead use < and >.

example.title: Example Mark-Up
example.programlisting:
<example id="example_example">
  <title>Example Mark-Up</title>
  <programlisting>public class ServiceName extends javax.xml.ws.Service
{
  ...
  public ServiceName(URL wsdlLocation, QName serviceName) { }
  
  public ServiceName() { }

  public Greeter getPortName() { }
  .
  .
  .
}

section.title: Code Blocks
section.para: There are cases when you need to use a block of code, but do not need to create a formal example with a title. In such cases you can use one of two methods:

In terms of the generated output, there is no difference between the two approaches. The real difference is in the complexity of the mark-up and the formality of the structure you wish to use. In the CXF documentation, the preferred method is to simply use the programlisting element. However, if you feel that a code block needs to be wrapped in an informalexample element, that is fine.

section.title: In-line Code
section.para: There are many instances where you need to place a code artifact in a block of text such as when you are referring to a Java class or an XML element. Docbook has a number of specialized elements for placing code artifacts in-line. The ones used in CXF include:

section.title: XML Artifacts
section.para: When placing XML artifacts such as element names or attribute names in your text wrap them in an sgmltag element. To specify the type of XML artifact, the sgmltag element's class attribute is always used. shows the values used for the class attribute.

row.entry: Value
Description
Specifies that the artifact is an attribute of an XML element.
Specifies that the artifact is an XML element.
Specifies that the artifact is the value of an XML element's attribute.
Specifies an XML element that does not hold any data such as foo.

section.title: General Programming Language Artifacts
section.para: Docbook defines a number of in-line tags for specifying programming artifacts. The CXF documentation makes use of the tags listed in .

row.entry: Element
Description
Specifies that the artifact is a data type such as int.
Specifies that the artifact is a constant such as NULL or 9.
Specifies that the artifact is an exception. It could be the name of the exception or the name of the class that implements the exception.
Specifies that the artifact is a function such as println().
Specifies that the artifact is a parameter to a function or a method.
Specifies that the artifact is a variable.

section.title: Object Oriented Programming Language Artifacts
section.para: In addition to the elements listed in , Docbook defines three elements that are used specifically for object-oriented programming artifacts. They are listed in .

table.title: Elements for In-Line OO Programming Artifacts

row.entry: Element
Description
Specifies that the artifact is a Java interface the user must implement.
Specifies that the artifact is a Java interface the user must implement. Requires the use of an modifier element that contains details about if the interface is public or private.
Specifies that the artifact is a Java class or an instantiated object.
Specifies that the artifact is a Java class. Requires the use of an modifier element that contains details about if the class is public/private or static/final.
Specifies that the artifact is a method. Methods are different from functions in that methods are associated with classes and objects.
Specifies that the artifact is a Java exception. Requires the use of an modifier element that contains details about if the exception is public or private.
